How to recognise your ABASAGLAR Tempo pen:

• Pen colour: Light grey

• Dose Knob: Light grey

• Labels: Light grey with green colour bars

Supplies needed to give your injection:

• Tempo Pen containing your insulin

• Tempo Pen compatible needle (BD [Becton, Dickinson and Company] pen needles recommended)

• Swab

Needles and swab are not included.

Preparing your pen

• Wash your hands with soap and water.

• Check the pen to make sure you are taking the right type of insulin. This is especially important if you use more than 1 type of insulin.

• Do not use your pen past the expiration date printed on the pen label or for more than 28 days after you first start using the pen.

• Always use a new needle for each injection to help prevent infections and blocked needles.

Step 1:

• Pull the pen cap straight off.

– Do not remove the pen label.

• Wipe the rubber seal with a swab.

ABASAGLAR should look clear and colourless. Do not use if it is cloudy, coloured, or has particles or clumps in it.

Step 2:

• Select a new needle.

• Pull off the paper tab from the outer needle shield.

Step 3:

• Push the capped needle straight onto the pen and twist the needle on until it is tight.

Step 4:

• Pull off the outer needle shield. Do not throw it away.

• Pull off the inner needle shield and throw it away.

Priming your pen

Prime before each injection.

• Priming your pen means removing the air from the needle and cartridge that may collect during normal use and ensures that the pen is working correctly.

• If you do not prime before each injection, you may get too much or too little insulin.

Step 5:

• To prime your pen, turn the dose knob to select 2 units.

Step 6:

• Hold your pen with the needle pointing up. Tap the cartridge holder gently to collect air bubbles at the top.

Step 7:

• Continue holding your pen with needle pointing up. Push the dose knob in until it stops, and “0” is seen in the dose window. Hold the dose knob in and count to 5 slowly.

You should see insulin at the tip of the needle.

– If you do not see insulin, repeat the priming steps, but not more than 4 times.

– If you still do not see insulin, change the needle and repeat the priming steps.

Small air bubbles are normal and will not affect your dose.

Selecting your dose

• You can give from 1 to 80 units in a single injection.

• If your dose is more than 80 units, you will need to give more than one injection.

– If you need help deciding how to divide up your dose, ask your healthcare professional.

– You should use a new needle for each injection and repeat the priming step.

Step 8:

• Turn the dose knob to select the number of units you need to inject. The dose indicator should line up with your dose.

– The pen dials 1 unit at a time.

– The dose knob clicks as you turn it.

– DO NOT dial your dose by counting the clicks because you may dial the wrong dose.

– The dose can be corrected by turning the dose knob in either direction until the correct dose lines up with the dose indicator.

– The even numbers are printed on the dial.

– The odd numbers, after the number 1, are shown as full lines.

• Always check the number in the dose window to make sure you have dialled the correct dose.

• The pen will not let you dial more than the number of units left in the pen.

• If you need to inject more than the number of units left in the pen, you may either:

– inject the amount left in your pen and then use a new pen to give the rest of your dose, or

– get a new pen and inject the full dose.

• It is normal to see a small amount of insulin left in the pen that you cannot inject.

Giving your injection

• Inject your insulin as your healthcare professional has shown you.

• Change (rotate) your injection site for each injection.

• Do not try to change your dose while injecting.

Step 9:

Choose your injection site.

• ABASAGLAR is injected under the skin (subcutaneously) of your stomach area, buttocks, upper legs or upper arms.

• Prepare your skin as recommended by your healthcare professional.

Step 10:

• Insert the needle into your skin.

• Push the dose knob all the way in.

• Continue to hold the dose knob in and slowly count to 5 before removing the needle.

Do not try to inject your insulin by turning the dose knob. You will NOT receive your insulin by turning the dose knob.

Step 11:

• Pull the needle out of your skin.

– A drop of insulin at the needle tip is normal. It will not affect your dose.

• Check the number in the dose window

– If you see “0” in the dose window, you have received the full amount you dialled.

– If you do not see “0” in the dose window, do not redial. Insert the needle into your skin and finish your injection.

– If you still do not think you received the full amount you dialled for your injection, do not start over or repeat that injection. Monitor your blood glucose as instructed by your healthcare professional.

– If you normally need to give 2 injections for your full dose, be sure to give your second injection.

The plunger only moves a little with each injection, and you may not notice that it moves.

If you see blood after you take the needle out of your skin, press the injection site lightly with a piece of gauze or swab. Do not rub the area.

After your injection


Step 12:

• Carefully replace the outer needle shield.

Step 13:

• Unscrew the capped needle and dispose of it as described below (see Disposing of pens and needles section).

• Do not store the pen with the needle attached to prevent leaking, blocking the needle, and air from entering the pen.

Step 14:

• Replace the pen cap by lining up the cap clip with the dose indicator and pushing straight on.

Disposing of pens and needles

• Put used needles in a closable, puncture-resistant sharps container.

• Do not recycle the filled sharps container.

• Ask your healthcare professional about options to dispose of the pens and sharps container properly.

• The directions regarding needle handling are not intended to replace local, healthcare professional or institutional policies.

Storing your pen

Unused pens

• Store unused pens in the refrigerator at (2 °C to 8 °C).

• Do not freeze ABASAGLAR. Do not use if it has been frozen.

• Unused pens may be used until the expiration date printed on the label, if the pen has been kept in the refrigerator.

In-use pen

• Store the pen you are currently using at room temperature [below (30 °C)] and away from dust, food and liquids, heat and light.

• Throw away the pen you are using after 28 days, even if it still has insulin left in it.

General information about the safe and effective use of your pen

• Keep your pen and needles out of the sight and reach of children.

• Do not use your pen if any part looks broken or damaged.

• Always carry an extra pen in case yours is lost or damaged.

Troubleshooting

• If you cannot remove the pen cap, gently twist the cap back and forth, and then pull the cap straight off.

• If the dose knob is hard to push:

– Pushing the dose knob more slowly will make it easier to inject.

– Your needle may be blocked. Put on a new needle and prime the pen.

– You may have dust, food, or liquid inside the pen. Throw the pen away and get a new pen. You may need to get a prescription from your healthcare professional.

If you have any questions or problems with your ABASAGLAR Tempo Pen, contact your healthcare professional for help.

Element: Warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia
Text: Warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia

Element: - In your body
Text: - In your body

Element: Examples of symptoms that tell you that your blood sugar level is falling too much or too fast: sweating, clammy skin, anxiety, fast heart beat, high blood pressure, palpitations and irregular heartbeat. These symptoms often develop before the symptoms of a low sugar level in the brain.
Text: Examples of symptoms that tell you that your blood sugar level is falling too much or too fast: sweating, clammy skin, anxiety, fast heart beat, high blood pressure, palpitations and irregular heartbeat. These symptoms often develop before the symptoms of a low sugar level in the brain.

Element: - In your brain
Text: - In your brain

Element: Examples of symptoms that indicate a low sugar level in the brain: headaches, intense hunger, nausea, vomiting, tiredness, sleepiness, sleep disturbances, restlessness, aggressive behaviour, lapses in concentration, impaired reactions, depression, confusion, speech disturbances (sometimes total loss of speech), visual disorders, trembling, paralysis, tingling sensations (paraesthesia), numbness and tingling sensations in the area of the mouth, dizziness, loss of self-control, inability to look after yourself, convulsions, loss of consciousness.
Text: Examples of symptoms that indicate a low sugar level in the brain: headaches, intense hunger, nausea, vomiting, tiredness, sleepiness, sleep disturbances, restlessness, aggressive behaviour, lapses in concentration, impaired reactions, depression, confusion, speech disturbances (sometimes total loss of speech), visual disorders, trembling, paralysis, tingling sensations (paraesthesia), numbness and tingling sensations in the area of the mouth, dizziness, loss of self-control, inability to look after yourself, convulsions, loss of consciousness.

Element: The first symptoms which alert you to hypoglycaemia ("warning symptoms") may change, be weaker or may be missing altogether if
Text: The first symptoms which alert you to hypoglycaemia ("warning symptoms") may change, be weaker or may be missing altogether if

Element: - you are elderly, if you have had diabetes for a long time or if you suffer from a certain type of nervous disease (diabetic autonomic neuropathy),
Text: -        you are elderly, if you have had diabetes for a long time or if you suffer from a certain type of nervous disease (diabetic autonomic neuropathy),

Element: - you have recently suffered hypoglycaemia (for example the day before) or if it develops slowly,
Text: -        you have recently suffered hypoglycaemia (for example the day before) or if it develops slowly,

Element: - you have almost normal or, at least, greatly improved blood sugar levels,
Text: -        you have almost normal or, at least, greatly improved blood sugar levels,

Element: - you have recently changed from an animal insulin to a human insulin such as ABASAGLAR,
Text: -        you have recently changed from an animal insulin to a human insulin such as ABASAGLAR,

Element: - you are taking or have taken certain other medicines (see section 2, "Other medicines and ABASAGLAR").
Text: -        you are taking or have taken certain other medicines (see section 2, "Other medicines and ABASAGLAR").

Element: In such a case, you may develop severe hypoglycaemia (and even faint) before you are aware of the problem. Be familiar with your warning symptoms. If necessary, more frequent blood sugar testing can help to identify mild hypoglycaemic episodes that may otherwise be overlooked. If you are not confident about recognising your warning symptoms, avoid situations (such as driving a car) in which you or others would be put at risk by hypoglycaemia.
Text: In such a case, you may develop severe hypoglycaemia (and even faint) before you are aware of the problem. Be familiar with your warning symptoms. If necessary, more frequent blood sugar testing can help to identify mild hypoglycaemic episodes that may otherwise be overlooked. If you are not confident about recognising your warning symptoms, avoid situations (such as driving a car) in which you or others would be put at risk by hypoglycaemia.

Element: What should you do if you experience hypoglycaemia?
Text: What should you do if you experience hypoglycaemia?

Element: 1. Do not inject insulin. Immediately take about 10 to 20 g sugar, such as glucose, sugar cubes or a sugar-sweetened beverage. Caution: Artificial sweeteners and foods with artificial sweeteners (such as diet drinks) are of no help in treating hypoglycaemia.
Text: 1. Do not inject insulin. Immediately take about 10 to 20 g sugar, such as glucose, sugar cubes or a sugar-sweetened beverage. Caution: Artificial sweeteners and foods with artificial sweeteners (such as diet drinks) are of no help in treating hypoglycaemia.

Element: 2. Then eat something that has a long-acting effect in raising your blood sugar (such as bread or pasta). Your doctor or nurse should have discussed this with you previously.
Text: 2. Then eat something that has a long-acting effect in raising your blood sugar (such as bread or pasta). Your doctor or nurse should have discussed this with you previously.

Element: The recovery of hypoglycaemia may be delayed because ABASAGLAR has a long action.'
Text: The recovery of hypoglycaemia may be delayed because ABASAGLAR has a long action.'

Element: 3. If the hypoglycaemia comes back again, take another 10 to 20 g sugar.
Text: 3. If the hypoglycaemia comes back again, take another 10 to 20 g sugar.

Element: 4. Speak to a doctor immediately if you are not able to control the hypoglycaemia or if it recurs. Tell your relatives, friends and close colleagues the following:
Text: 4. Speak to a doctor immediately if you are not able to control the hypoglycaemia or if it recurs. Tell your relatives, friends and close colleagues the following:

Element: If you are not able to swallow or if you are unconscious, you will require an injection of glucose or glucagon (a medicine which increases blood sugar). These injections are justified even if it is not certain that you have hypoglycaemia.
Text: If you are not able to swallow or if you are unconscious, you will require an injection of glucose or glucagon (a medicine which increases blood sugar). These injections are justified even if it is not certain that you have hypoglycaemia.

Element: It is advisable to test your blood sugar immediately after taking glucose to check that you really have hypoglycaemia.
Text: It is advisable to test your blood sugar immediately after taking glucose to check that you really have hypoglycaemia.

Element: Read the instructions for use before you start using ABASAGLAR and each time you get another ABASAGLAR Tempo Pen. There may be new information. This information does not take the place of talking to your healthcare professional about your medical condition or your treatment.
Text: Read the instructions for use before you start using ABASAGLAR and each time you get another ABASAGLAR Tempo Pen. There may be new information. This information does not take the place of talking to your healthcare professional about your medical condition or your treatment.

Element: ABASAGLAR Tempo Pen (“Pen”) is a disposable prefilled pen containing 300 units (3 mL) of insulin glargine. You can give yourself multiple doses using one pen. The pen dials 1 unit at a time. You can give from 1 to 80 units in a single injection. If your dose is more than 80 units, you will need to give yourself more than one injection. The plunger only moves a little with each injection, and you may not notice that it moves. The plunger will only reach the end of the cartridge when you have used all 300 units in the pen.
Text: ABASAGLAR Tempo Pen (“Pen”) is a disposable prefilled pen containing 300 units (3 mL) of insulin glargine. You can give yourself multiple doses using one pen. The pen dials 1 unit at a time. You can give from 1 to 80 units in a single injection. If your dose is more than 80 units, you will need to give yourself more than one injection. The plunger only moves a little with each injection, and you may not notice that it moves. The plunger will only reach the end of the cartridge when you have used all 300 units in the pen.

Element: The Tempo Pen is designed to work with the Tempo Smart Button. The Tempo Smart Button is an optional product that can be attached to the Tempo Pen dose knob and aids in transmitting Abasaglar dose information from the Tempo Pen to a compatible mobile application. The Tempo Pen injects insulin with or without the Tempo Smart Button attached. Your Smart Button must be attached to a Tempo Pen to record or transfer dose data. Push the Smart Button straight down on the dose knob until you hear a snap or feel the Smart Button snap into place. To transmit data to the mobile application, follow the instructions provided with the Tempo Smart Button and the instructions with the mobile application.

Element: Preparing your pen
Text: Preparing your pen

Element: • Wash your hands with soap and water.
Text: •     Wash your hands with soap and water.

Element: • Check the pen to make sure you are taking the right type of insulin. This is especially important if you use more than 1 type of insulin.
Text: •     Check the pen to make sure you are taking the right type of insulin. This is especially important if you use more than 1 type of insulin.

Element: • Do not use your pen past the expiration date printed on the pen label or for more than 28 days after you first start using the pen.
Text: •     Do not use your pen past the expiration date printed on the pen label or for more than 28 days after you first start using the pen.

Element: • Always use a new needle for each injection to help prevent infections and blocked needles.
Text: •     Always use a new needle for each injection to help prevent infections and blocked needles.

Element:
Step 1:

• Pull the pen cap straight off.

– Do not remove the pen label.

• Wipe the rubber seal with a swab.

ABASAGLAR should look clear and colourless. Do not use if it is cloudy, coloured, or has particles or clumps in it.

Step 2:

• Select a new needle.

• Pull off the paper tab from the outer needle shield.

Step 3:

• Push the capped needle straight onto the pen and twist the needle on until it is tight.

Step 4:

• Pull off the outer needle shield. Do not throw it away.

• Pull off the inner needle shield and throw it away.

Element: Priming your pen
Text: Priming your pen

Element: Prime before each injection.
Text: Prime before each injection.

Element: • Priming your pen means removing the air from the needle and cartridge that may collect during normal use and ensures that the pen is working correctly.
Text: •     Priming your pen means removing the air from the needle and cartridge that may collect during normal use and ensures that the pen is working correctly.

Element: • If you do not prime before each injection, you may get too much or too little insulin.
Text: •     If you do not prime before each injection, you may get too much or too little insulin.

Element:
Step 5:

• To prime your pen, turn the dose knob to select 2 units.

Step 6:

• Hold your pen with the needle pointing up. Tap the cartridge holder gently to collect air bubbles at the top.

Step 7:

• Continue holding your pen with needle pointing up. Push the dose knob in until it stops, and “0” is seen in the dose window. Hold the dose knob in and count to 5 slowly.

You should see insulin at the tip of the needle.

– If you do not see insulin, repeat the priming steps, but not more than 4 times.

– If you still do not see insulin, change the needle and repeat the priming steps.

Small air bubbles are normal and will not affect your dose.

Element: Selecting your dose
Text: Selecting your dose

Element: • You can give from 1 to 80 units in a single injection.
Text: •     You can give from 1 to 80 units in a single injection.

Element: • If your dose is more than 80 units, you will need to give more than one injection.
Text: •     If your dose is more than 80 units, you will need to give more than one injection.

Element: – If you need help deciding how to divide up your dose, ask your healthcare professional.
Text: –    If you need help deciding how to divide up your dose, ask your healthcare professional.

Element: – You should use a new needle for each injection and repeat the priming step.
Text: –    You should use a new needle for each injection and repeat the priming step.

Element: <br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always"/>

Step 8:

• Turn the dose knob to select the number of units you need to inject. The dose indicator should line up with your dose.

– The pen dials 1 unit at a time.

– The dose knob clicks as you turn it.

– DO NOT dial your dose by counting the clicks because you may dial the wrong dose.

– The dose can be corrected by turning the dose knob in either direction until the correct dose lines up with the dose indicator.

– The even numbers are printed on the dial.

– The odd numbers, after the number 1, are shown as full lines.

• Always check the number in the dose window to make sure you have dialled the correct dose.

Element: • The pen will not let you dial more than the number of units left in the pen.

Element: • If you need to inject more than the number of units left in the pen, you may either:
Text: •     If you need to inject more than the number of units left in the pen, you may either:

Element: – inject the amount left in your pen and then use a new pen to give the rest of your dose, or
Text: –    inject the amount left in your pen and then use a new pen to give the rest of your dose, or

Element: – get a new pen and inject the full dose.

Element: Giving your injection
Text: Giving your injection

Element: • Inject your insulin as your healthcare professional has shown you.
Text: •     Inject your insulin as your healthcare professional has shown you.

Element: • Change (rotate) your injection site for each injection.
Text: •     Change (rotate) your injection site for each injection.

Element: • Do not try to change your dose while injecting.
Text: •     Do not try to change your dose while injecting.

Element:
Step 9:

Choose your injection site.

• ABASAGLAR is injected under the skin (subcutaneously) of your stomach area, buttocks, upper legs or upper arms.

• Prepare your skin as recommended by your healthcare professional.

Step 10:

• Insert the needle into your skin.

• Push the dose knob all the way in.

• Continue to hold the dose knob in and slowly count to 5 before removing the needle.

Do not try to inject your insulin by turning the dose knob. You will NOT receive your insulin by turning the dose knob.

Step 11:

• Pull the needle out of your skin.

– A drop of insulin at the needle tip is normal. It will not affect your dose.

• Check the number in the dose window

– If you see “0” in the dose window, you have received the full amount you dialled.

– If you do not see “0” in the dose window, do not redial. Insert the needle into your skin and finish your injection.

– If you still do not think you received the full amount you dialled for your injection, do not start over or repeat that injection. Monitor your blood glucose as instructed by your healthcare professional.

– If you normally need to give 2 injections for your full dose, be sure to give your second injection.

The plunger only moves a little with each injection, and you may not notice that it moves.

If you see blood after you take the needle out of your skin, press the injection site lightly with a piece of gauze or swab. Do not rub the area.

Step 12:

• Carefully replace the outer needle shield.

Step 13:

• Unscrew the capped needle and dispose of it as described below (see Disposing of pens and needles section).

• Do not store the pen with the needle attached to prevent leaking, blocking the needle, and air from entering the pen.

Step 14:

• Replace the pen cap by lining up the cap clip with the dose indicator and pushing straight on.

Element: Storing your pen
Text: Storing your pen

Element: Unused pens
Text: Unused pens

Element: • Store unused pens in the refrigerator at (2 °C to 8 °C).
Text: •     Store unused pens in the refrigerator at (2 °C to 8 °C).

Element: • Do not freeze ABASAGLAR. Do not use if it has been frozen.
Text: •     Do not freeze ABASAGLAR. Do not use if it has been frozen.

Element: • Unused pens may be used until the expiration date printed on the label, if the pen has been kept in the refrigerator.
Text: •     Unused pens may be used until the expiration date printed on the label, if the pen has been kept in the refrigerator.

Element: In-use pen
Text: In-use pen

Element: • Store the pen you are currently using at room temperature [below (30 °C)] and away from dust, food and liquids, heat and light.
Text: •     Store the pen you are currently using at room temperature [below (30 °C)] and away from dust, food and liquids, heat and light.

Element: • Throw away the pen you are using after 28 days, even if it still has insulin left in it.
Text: •     Throw away the pen you are using after 28 days, even if it still has insulin left in it.

Element: General information about the safe and effective use of your pen
Text: General information about the safe and effective use of your pen

Element: • Keep your pen and needles out of the sight and reach of children.
Text: •     Keep your pen and needles out of the sight and reach of children.

Element: • Do not use your pen if any part looks broken or damaged.
Text: •     Do not use your pen if any part looks broken or damaged.

Element: • Always carry an extra pen in case yours is lost or damaged.
Text: •     Always carry an extra pen in case yours is lost or damaged.

Element: Troubleshooting

Element: • If you cannot remove the pen cap, gently twist the cap back and forth, and then pull the cap straight off.

Element: • If the dose knob is hard to push:
Text: •     If the dose knob is hard to push:

Element: – Pushing the dose knob more slowly will make it easier to inject.
Text: –    Pushing the dose knob more slowly will make it easier to inject.

Element: – Your needle may be blocked. Put on a new needle and prime the pen.
Text: –    Your needle may be blocked. Put on a new needle and prime the pen.

Element: – You may have dust, food, or liquid inside the pen. Throw the pen away and get a new pen. You may need to get a prescription from your healthcare professional.
